awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Metal hydride technology to miniaturize and provide new cooling or heating  solutions
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a reusable metal hydride-based device for energy storage. The project will provide a compact and inexpensive cooling device for a wide range of markets.  Potential applications of the metal hydride technology are in batteries, hydrogen storage materials, and thermal energy storage to harness excess energy and provide on-demand sustainable energy. Current metal hydride-based device storage devices largely work only at temperature extremes, which limit their application in conventional storage systems. Thus, strategies are needed to develop storage devices for use at ambient conditions. The proposed technology may provide an efficient method for energy storage that will be a key enabler for future clean energy technologies.

This I-Corps project develops a cooling device that is driven by solid-gas reactions between a pair of alloys and hydrogen. Hydrogen storage by metal hydrides is accomplished by an intermetallic alloy phase that has the ability to absorb and store atomic hydrogen in interstitial sites of the metal lattice. Forcing the intermetallic alloy phase to release the absorbed hydrogen leads to an endothermic reaction which results in cooling. Various metal hydrides have been investigated to determine the hydrogen absorption/desorption pathways and to identify the thermodynamic requirements necessary for dehydrogenation reactions with an equilibrium close to ambient conditions. Preliminary results have shown that at ambient conditions the metal hydride can be recharged 10,000 times with only 10% loss of capacity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the I-Corps project led by the Chill Tech research team was to explore potential markets for a reusable metal hydride-based cooling device. This technology, with its exceptional heat and mass transfer characteristics, is set to revolutionize thermal energy storage by harnessing low-quality thermal energy sources to provide an on-demand, sustainable cooling supply. The compactness, efficiency, reusability, silent operation, and affordability of metal hydrides make them suitable for unique and power-efficient cooling applications. During this project, the research team engaged directly with potential customers, stepping out of the laboratory environment to gain first-hand insights. The team analyzed the potential of metal hydride-based cooling technology by interviewing over 100 potential customers.

The team tested three hypotheses with potential users of the technology. First, the idea of a portable device for on-demand fluid cooling was evaluated through 32 interviews of stakeholders in the small-to-medium scale food and beverage sector. Second, a portable and reusable cooling system's proposition for the Medical Industry was assessed based on 6 interviews. Lastly, the team explored the potential of metal hydride-based air conditioning technology via 82 interviews within the HVAC Industry. Through these discussions, the team learned that consumers were generally less aware of their technology compared to businesses, except in high utility expense areas like California where homeowners demonstrated more understanding of their HVAC unit’s energy consumption.

Of these three hypotheses, the HVAC industry expressed the most substantial need for innovation, particularly to improve energy consumption, workflow, and reliability. Industry professionals voiced concerns about the installation and service process for existing units, and the increasing pressure to conform to new government regulations banning hydrocarbon-based refrigerants. The consensus was clear: a new technology is needed to tackle these modern industry challenges.

Without the fieldwork conducted by the research team, these insights might have been overlooked. The findings allow the team to focus on developing tailored solutions that meet industry needs. By the end of the interview process, the team had logged 130 meaningful discussions that can serve as a valuable reference for future research.

The project also served as an opportunity for training research personnel to objectively view their discussions and evaluate if the questions proposed led to meaningful data collection. This experience has equipped the team with the skills to formulate meaningful questions that validate new technology development.

Going forward, the Chill Tech research team plans to form Hydracool LLC to pursue funding from NSF, DOE, EPA, and other government agencies through SBIR/STTR programs. The needs of the HVAC industry will be at the forefront of the company's R&D focus, ensuring future funding opportunities align with real-world applications.
